title: 104_hr3727
content: The Act may be cited as the "ATM Fee Reform Act of 1996" and requires electronic fund transfer fee disclosures at any host ATM. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to require fee disclosures at electronic terminals by host operators providing transfer services to consumers. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to require fee disclosures at electronic terminals by host operators providing transfer services to consumers. The notice must be prominently displayed on the terminal before the consumer commits to the transaction. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to require fee disclosures at electronic terminals by host operators. No fee can be imposed unless the consumer receives proper notice and elects to continue with the transaction. SEC. 3. AGENCY REPORTS OF COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATION E. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to include balance inquiries as electronic fund transfers. Agencies must submit annual reports to Congress on compliance with regulations, including trends in fees imposed by host ATM operators. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to include balance inquiries as electronic fund transfers. Agencies must submit annual reports to Congress on compliance with regulations, including trends in fees imposed by host ATM operators. The information required for submission to Congress may be included in any other annual report by the agency. SEC. 4. DISCLOSURE OF POSSIBLE FEES TO CONSUMERS WHEN ATM CARD IS ISSUED. This section amends the Electronic Fund Transfer Act to require written notice to account holders about possible fees imposed by electronic terminal operators and networks when initiating fund transfers. SEC. 5. FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on prohibiting fees for electronic fund transfers initiated by consumers through electronic terminals unless a notice is provided stating the amount of the fee by the terminal operator, financial institution, and network involved. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on factors related to the notice requirement for prohibiting fees on electronic fund transfers, considering technology availability, costs, competitive impact, implementation time, and consumer benefits. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of the Act, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations regarding the feasibility of implementing a notice requirement for prohibiting fees on electronic fund transfers. The report will also consider any other factors deemed relevant by the Comptroller General.
